data.text:
Fans of the Great American Songbook know Vernon Duke (1903-1969) as the composer of the immortal standards “April in Paris” (1932), “I Can’t Get Started” (1936), and “Autumn in New York” (1934). The first two feature lyrics by Yip Harburg and Ira Gershwin, respectively, but the last is all his, words and music:

Autumn in New York —

Why does it seem so inviting?

Autumn in New York —

It spells the thrill of first-nighting.

Glittering crowds and shimmering clouds

In canyons of steel —

They’re making me feel… I’m home.

Not bad, for a man who had only come to the United States just over a decade earlier. Duke, or Vladimir Dukelsky, was born to a noble Russian family in 1903, in what is now Belarus, and was trained as a composer at the Kyiv Conservatory. Displaced by the Civil War, the family settled briefly in Constantinople — where the young composer, stretching his wings, founded a Poets’ Guild with Boris Poplavsky (1903-1935), one of the most original voices of the Russian emigration — before obtaining visas and setting sail for Ellis Island.

Soon enough, Dukeslsky found his footing as a popular tunesmith under the name Duke (an abbreviation suggested by George Gershwin, né Gershowitz), but he continued to compose modernist classical works under his original name. What’s more, he continued to write poems in Russian — poems closer in spirit to “Autumn in New York” than to the surreal visions of his confrere Poplavsky.

Dukelsky was an essentially buoyant man, with a dash of ironic ruefulness — a mix of traits that comes through not only in his popular compositions, but also in his autobiography, Passport to Paris (1955). It’s also evident in the title of his second collection of Russian verse, The Sorrows of Elderly Werther, which was published in Munich in 1962, but was mostly written in Los Angeles, where he lived happily until his death in 1969.

The Sorrows includes an entire sequence of poems dedicated to Los Angeles: portraits of a faded movie star on Sunset Blvd., a toothless beatnik in Venice Beach, an old heiress in Beverly Hills, etc. But my favorite of these is an ecstatic blank verse ode to the Farmers Market on 3rd St. and Fairfax Ave., where I’ve whiled away months upon months of Sundays, from high school on; it’s hard not to enjoy the place innocently, and Duke rightly contrasts his experience with that of the great Symbolist poet Alexander Blok (1880-1921), who, on his visits to St. Petersburg nightspots, was forever seeking the Beautiful Lady but kept running into apparitions and mysterious strangers.

Founded in 1934 in order to support struggling farmers during the Great Depression, the Market has been in continuous operation ever since. It remains partly open during the current global shutdown, and I have every confidence that it will survive. But I do wish Jenny and I could stroll down there this very minute and enjoy the bustling scene Duke describes… Until that day comes, we’ll let our imaginations do the work.

Farmers Market

Plump little clouds, like rolls of bread,

lie on the sky’s blue tablecloth.

The sun is orange marmalade

scooped generously from the jar.

Breakfast is ready, it would seem,

but we will never reach that high —

besides, our time has not yet come:

we’re plenty happy where we are.

Just show us to the Farmers Market,

that citadel of gluttony,

lavish abode fit for Lucullus,

where fruits and vegetables and flowers

arch like a rainbow over earth

and dazzle countless looky-loos.

The meat upon a nearby tray

is ruddy with ferocious health —

at any moment it might leap

right down and turn into a calf.

A fresh-caught fish puffs out its cheeks

and gives a crab a flirty wink;

its scales still drip with salty water,

all iridescent, nacre-like.

Bronze-colored coffee from Brazil

does battle with the sea’s strong smell,

but both are in the end defeated

by the aroma of the dill,

the savory odor of Dutch cheese,

the serenade of gorgonzola.

To right and left are restaurants,

and also strangers, apparitions —

but not the type you find in Blok,

just average girls, everyday women.

Beautiful Ladies don’t abound.

Some are in trousers, some in skirts.

No mysteries — it’s clear as day:

teeth gleaming, bosoms ample, fragrant —

all attributes are on display,

and there’s no need to get acquainted.

Let’s sit down at the nearest table,

and I will go and fetch — your choice! —

Mexican rice flavored with saffron,

a salmon of the palest pink,

a lobster with two piercing whiskers,

sweet buttered cobs of golden corn…

Perhaps Italian minestrone?

Or a grey soup of swallow’s nests,

prepared, of course, a la Chinoise?

There is no perfume, no thick fog —

all is so obvious, so plain,

and tuneful without any music:

a purely thoughtless tenderness,

uncomplicated happiness —

and that, my dear, will do for us.

January 1, 1962

Farmers’ Market

Небо — голубая скатерть,

Облака на нём, как булки,

Солнце — будто как из банки

Апельсинное варенье;

Приготовлен, видно, завтрак —

Но до неба не дотянешь,

Нам туда ещё не время,

Мы довольны и землёю,

Покажи мне Farmers’ Market,

Цитадель чревоугодья.

Обиталище Лукулла.

Овощи, цветы и фрукты

Там, как радуга земная,

Ослепляют любопытных;

Мясо на лотке соседнем

Брызжет яростным здоровьем.

Погоди — вот, вот подпрыгнет

И окажется телёнком.

Рыба надувает щёки

И подмигивает крабу;

Чешуя слезится морем

И сверкает перламутром.

С запахом морским воюет

Бронзовый бразильский кофе.

Но обоих побеждает

Дух пронзительный укропа,

Сыр голландский благовонный,

Серенада горгонзолы.

Справа, слева — рестораны,

Невидимки, незнакомки,

Не такие, как у Блока —

Просто девушки и дамы.

Но Прекрасных дам немного —

Кто — в штанах, иные в юбках;

Всё на месте, без мистерий —

Зубы блещут, грудь на выкат,

Под рукой все аттрибуты —

И знакомиться не надо.

Сядем за ближайший столик —

Принесу тебе на выбор

Мексиканский рис шафранный,

Бледнорозовую сёмгу,

Длинноусого лангуста,

Золотую кукурузу,

Итальянский minestrone

Или ласточкины гнёзда

В сером супе, по китайски.

Нет духов и нет туманов,

Всё до одури понятно

И без музыки певуче:

Необдуманная нежность,

Незатейливое счастье —

Нам довольно и такого.

1 января 1962
